description: From Middle French oppugner Latin oppugno (“fight against, to attack, assail, assault, storm, besiege, war with”).

verbs.description: oppugn (third-person singular simple present oppugns, present participle oppugning, simple past and past participle oppugned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To contradict or controvert; to oppose; to challenge or question the truth or validity of a given statement.
examples: It is for the same reason, that is, because 'tis all comprehended in Slawkenbergius, that I say nothing likewise of Scroderus (Andrea) who all the world knows, set himself to oppugn Prignitz with great violence, ---- proving it in his own way, first logically, and then by a series of stubborn facts
